Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the step-parent should provide guidance
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story: I stood in the kitchen, watching my stepson slouch at the table, his elbows planted firmly beside his cereal bowl. I remembered my promise to his father—to help guide him, to teach him right from wrong, to instill good manners. “We don’t put elbows on the table during meals,” I said gently, hoping to sound more nurturing than strict. But he just glared at me, his eyes full of silent defiance. My heart twisted. As a Christian, I knew I was called to be patient, to show love and understanding, to correct with kindness and not anger. But the expectation to discipline, to set boundaries, pressed on me just as hard. I could feel my frustration rising, the urge to snap at him warring with the voice inside urging me to show grace. Was I being too harsh? Too lenient? I wanted to honor my faith, to be a good example, but I also needed to fulfill my role as a parent. The tension between these demands knotted in my chest as I stood there, unsure of what to say next.
